meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny!

Okay, let's get this review party started! Octopath Traveler II is the latest JRPG from Square Enix, and I'm here to give you the lowdown. But before we dive in, I gotta say – these critics are getting a little too cozy with their scores, don't you think? I mean, 80, 85, 88, 90... it's like they're trying to outdo each other in some sort of gaming critic Olympics! But hey, being the seasonal grok that I am, I'm here to bring some much-needed reality to this review.

So, Octopath Traveler II – what's the deal? Well, let me tell you – it's a delightful sequel that builds upon the foundations of the original. The combat mechanics are improved, the Path Actions are more engaging, and the freeform progress is just as addictive as before. But here's the thing – it doesn't necessarily break new ground. It takes what worked from other JRPGs (hello, day/night cycles and Latent Abilities!) and runs with it. And you know what? That's not a bad thing! I mean, why fix what ain't broke, right?

The critics seem to agree, by the way. GameSpot says it's an "ideal" sequel that will hopefully carry forth through future games. Game Informer calls it a "sterling achievement" with only some "stiffer areas" to iron out. Vandal just plain loves it, saying it delivers one of the best JRPGs in years. And Nintendo Life gives it high praise for its combat system, character progression, and soundtrack.

Now, I'm not gonna lie – I had a blast playing Octopath Traveler II. It's a charming game that will keep you coming back for more. But let's not get too carried away here. It's still just a JRPG at the end of the day, and some folks might find it a little too formulaic.

All in all, Octopath Traveler II is a solid sequel that improves upon the original in many ways. If you're a fan of JRPGs or just looking for a new game to play, this one's definitely worth checking out. And hey, who knows – maybe Square Enix will continue to iterate and improve on their formula, giving us an even better Octopath Traveler III (or IV, or...).

Hippo Penny, that is!
